oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Young African American girls
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Five African American girls are gathered near a rickety wood fence and wood house. Several of the girls are smiling, though the surrounds suggest they live in dire poverty. They are all wearing plain sack dresses. A white woman wearing a long skirt can be seen in the background. She is walking away.
The humble sack dress was made from seed bags and flour bags. The dresses were standard wear for the poor. Later in the 20th century, print sack dresses were fashionable.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; African Americans; Girls; Fences; Bonnets; Clothing & dress
